Abstracts for the UIP XIX World Congress of Phlebology, 12–16 September 2022, Istanbul, Turkey

Mitochondrial DNA Impairments Affect Mitochondria’s Functional State in Varicose Veins

Mariya Smetanina1, Valeria Korolenya2, Ksenia Sevostyanova3, Konstantin Gavrilov3, Andrey Shevela3, Maxim Filipenko4

1(a) Laboratory of Pharmacogenomics, Institute of Chemical Biology and Fundamental Medicine, and (b) Department of Fundamental Medicine, Novosibirsk State University, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russia

2(a) Laboratory of Pharmacogenomics, Institute of Chemical Biology and Fundamental Medicine, and (b) Department of Natural Sciences, Novosibirsk State University, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russia

3(a) Center of New Medical Technologies, Institute of Chemical Biology and Fundamental Medicine, and (b) Department of Surgical Diseases, Novosibirsk State University, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russia

4(a) Laboratory of Pharmacogenomics, Institute of Chemical Biology and Fundamental Medicine, and (b) Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Novosibirsk State University, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russia

Background: Molecular pathogenesis of varicose vein disease is far from being understood. In our previous studies we showed the decreased mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) copy number and its impaired integrity in varicose veins. There is an evidence of the link between mtDNA copy number, mitochondrial membrane potential, oxygen consumption, and ATP synthesis. Varicose veins are characterized by endothelial dysfunction and reduction of smooth muscle cells’ contractile function. We aimed at investigating possible alterations of mitochondria functions (in in terms of mitochondrial membrane potential of the vein wall constituents: endothelial cells (ECs) and smooth muscle cells (SMCs) of t. intima and t. media layers, correspondingly) in varicose veins.

Methods: The study was conducted according to the principles written in the Declaration of Helsinki and approved by our institutional committee. Post-operation material of paired GSV samples (varicose (VV) and non-varicose (NV) vein segments left after surgery from a corresponding patient, C2-C4 CEAP classes) was placed in cell culture media and subjected to live-staining with mitochondrion-selective fluorescent probes: mitochondrial membrane potential-dependent TMRM and -independent MitoTracker Deep Red, as well as with nucleus-selective probe NucBlue. To visualize a particular vein wall layer, images were taken at different z-axis series using laser scanning confocal microscopy. Measurements of signal intensities were performed using ZEN 3.1 (blue edition) software (Zeiss, Germany). Relative levels of mitochondrial membrane potential were calculated as the [mitochondrial membrane potential-dependent/mitochondrial membrane potential-independent intensities] ratios within each cell/image field/sample. Statistical analysis was performed in Excel and STATISTICA packages, using Student's t-test (for comparison between multiple cells/image fields within a subgroup) and Wilcoxon-signed rank test (for comparison between paired NV and VV segments).

Results: We found that that mitochondrial membrane potential was decreased in ECs and SMCs of VV compared to NV segments 2.98- and 5.08-fold, correspondingly (n=5, p<0.05). The representative images are shown in Figure 1. More thorough analysis will be performed in the nearest future.

Conclusion: Though preliminary, these findings provide a possible link between vascular ECs and SMCs functional activity and their mtDNA content in varicose veins. The work was supported by the Russian Science Foundation (project No. 22-25-00832).

Keywords: varicose veins, endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, mitochondrial membrane potential

Mid-term and long-term results of various treatment strategies for patients with recurrent varicose veins of the lower extremities

Konstantin Chernykh1

1City Alexander Hospital

Background: The treatment of varicose veins of the lower extremities (VVLE) is an extremely urgent task. Comparison of different ways to eliminate this disease has always been the focus of attention of phlebologists.Target. Study of mid-term and long-term results of radiofrequency ablation (RFO) and endovasal laser ablation (EVLA) in patients with LVL.

Methods: For the period from 2013 - 2017, 257 EVLA (group 1) and 151 RFO (group 2) were performed at the City Alexander Hospital, St. Petersburg. For RFO, the radio frequency device Closure RFG was used. For EVLA, the ALOD-01 laser device with a wavelength of 1470 nm was used.

Results: All patients in 100% of cases came for examination after 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year and 2 years. After 1 month, according to the results of ultrasound examination (ultrasound), in 100% of cases, recanalization is not observed in both groups. In the first group, 85.6% (220) of patients had no pigmentation, 14.4% (37) still had pigmentation. In the second group, 23.2% (35) of patients did not have pigmentation, 76.8% (116) did. After 3 months, according to the results of ultrasound in 100% of cases, recanalization is not observed in both groups. In the first group in 100% of cases there is no pigmentation. In the second group, 72.2% (109) of patients did not have pigmentation, 27.8 (42) did. After 6 months, according to the results of ultrasound in patients of the first group, 100% of cases of recanalization are not observed, which is statistically significantly different from the structure of this symptom in patients of the second group (p<0.001): recanalization is observed in 29.8% (45) of patients, there is no recanalization only in 70.2% of patients. After 1 year, according to the results of ultrasound in patients of the first group, 100% of cases of recanalization are not observed, which is statistically significantly different from the structure of this symptom in patients of the second group (p<0.001): recanalization is observed in 29.8% (45) of patients, there is no recanalization only in 70.2% (106) of patients. After 2 years, according to the results of ultrasound in patients of the first group, 100% of cases of recanalization are not observed, which is statistically significantly different from the structure of this symptom in patients of the second group (p<0.001): recanalization is observed in 41.7 (63) patients, there is no recanalization only in 58.3% (88) of patients.

Conclusion: EVLA showed greater efficiency and low complication rate in the mid-term and long-term periods compared to RFO.

Keywords: endovasal laser ablation, varicose veins of the lower extremities, radiofrequency ablation

Radiation diagnosis of varicose veins of the pelvis of a man

Oleg Zhukov1

1Medical Institute of RUDN University

Background: A significant contribution to the syndrome of chronic pelvic pain in men is made by varicose transformation of the veins of the pelvis.

Methods: From September 2011 to September 2021, 568 patients with varicocele were examined. The age of patients ranged from 18 to 59 years and averaged 35.3±19.2 The examination included a survey, physical examination, ejaculate analysis, study of the level of sex hormones, Doppler ultrasound of the scrotum and TRUS of the prostate gland, MR phlebography of the inferior vena cava . Patients with varicocele and diagnosed infertility underwent surgical treatment - microsurgical varicocelectomy (Marmara) or endovascular sclerotherapy, with a relapse of the disease.

Results: Varicocele was left-sided in 361 (63.6%), right-sided in 9 (1.5%) and bilateral in 198 (34.9%) patients. In all cases, there was an expansion of the veins of the paraprostatic plexus on the side of the identified varicocele according to transrectal ultrasound. Stage 1 maximum diameter of paraprostatic veins on the affected side of the varicocele is less than 5 mm, blood flow velocity in the veins is less than 5 cm / s, the diameter does not change during the Valsalva maneuver, Stage 2 maximum diameter is more than 5 mm, the speed is 5-10 cm / s, during the Valsalva maneuver the diameter increases to 50% of the original, stage 3 the maximum diameter is more than 10 mm, the speed is more than 10 cm / s, with the Valsalva test, the diameter increases by more than 50% of the initial.

Conclusion: Our data indicate the relationship between varicocele and pelvic varicose veins in men.The use of our classification will improve the results of treatment of patients with varicocele

Keywords: varicose veins, male pelvis, TRUZI

Endovenous Laser Ablation 1940 nm, First 1000 Cases

Dmitrii Slavin1, Alexander Chugunov1, Ilsear Shamsutdinova2, Matvey Parikov3

1Kazan State Medical Academy, Russia

2Fleboestetic Clinic, Kazan, Russia

3Innovative vascular centre, Saint-Petersburg, Russia

Background: Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) of saphenous veins still has some controversies in optimal laser wavelength, treatment protocol and types of fibers. We have a ten years’ experience with 1470 and 1560 nm diode lasers for EVLA. In recent years we use a new wavelength 1940 nm and evaluate our results of the treatment.

Methods: 1000 patients from 2020, CEAP C2-C6. GSV 71,4%, SSV 11,4%, AASV 5,9%, GSV+SSV 4,8%, GSV+AASV 6,5%. Treated veins with a diameter of more than 15 mm - 10,8%. EVLA was performed on an ambulatory basis with tumescent anesthesia and 1940 nm laser (IPG Photonics Corporation, Russia). In all cases we used «thin» radial fibers with outer diameter 1,24 mm or 1,6 mm (Lightguide, Biolitec) and peripheral intravenous 16G or 14G catheters for cannulation. We used standard treatment protocol: continuous mode with power range 4-8 Watts, automatic fiber pull-back speed 0,75-1 mm/sec and LEED 40-106 J/cm dependent from the vein diameter. Relatively straight varicose tributaries were also treated with EVLA. In others cases concomitant phlebectomy or sclerotherapy of varicose tributaries was performed. Post-procedure compression indicated for 1-2 weeks. In postoperative period we evaluated the occlusion rate, duration of analgesics, endothermal heat induced thrombosis (EHIT) and other complications. Ultrasound imaging was performed on the 1st and 7th day and 6 months after the EVLA.

Results: Initial occlusion rate was 100%, only 1 recanalization (SSV) was observed 6 months after EVLA, taking into account that we reduced LEED to 40-106 J/cm compared with previous LEED of 67-160 J/cm with 1470/1560 nm lasers. We successfully treated veins with a diameter less than 0,8 cm with 1,2 mm radial fibers and veins more than 0.8 cm with 1,6 mm radial fibers, maximal diameter of the treated vein was 3 cm. Sometimes we also observed carbonization and sticking of the fiber tip. Analgesics were taken by only 6,7% of the patients on the first day after EVLA. Endothermal heat induced thrombosis was revealed in 0,8% of patients in the first two weeks: EHIT II – 0,6%, EHIT III – 0,2%. No burns, infections and pulmonary embolism occurred. We observed transient paresthesia in 3% of patients.

Conclusion: EVLA 1940 nm with radial fibers is highly effective, safe and painless procedure in the treatment of incompetent saphenous veins. According to our experience the postoperative period is the same compared with 1470/1560 nm lasers. But we can perform EVLA 1940 nm with a relatively low LEED and «thin» fibers without introdusers kits in all patients and in some cases we can also treated varicose tributaries.

Keywords: EVLA, 1940 nm, "thin" radial fiber

Venous disorders as an occupational disease: data, pathophysiology, and modification strategies

Tobias Hirsch1, Uwe Wahl2

1Practice for Internal Medicine and Vascular Diseases, Vein Competency Center, Halle (Saale), Germany

2BG Hospital Bergmannstrost Halle, Department of Internal Medicine, Halle (Saale), Germany

Background: Chronic Venous Disease (CVD) is closely linked to the modern working world. Tasks carried out in a standing or seated position play a role in the development of venous disorders. Though not commonly recognized as an occupational disease, venous disorders must be taken into account in the design of workspaces. This review aims to analyze the literature on the relationship between CVD and occupational exposure.

Growth of the tertiary economic sector and the prevalence of CVD

(a) There are 3 economic sectors: the primary sector of raw material production (blue), the secondary manufacturing sector (orange) and the tertiary service sector (grey). While the primary economic sector is characterized by a high level of physical activity, standing and sitting activities dominate the secondary and tertiary sectors. (b) The dominant increase of the tertiary sector is connected to an increase of the prevalence of the CVD.

Methods: A systematic review through Pubmed and the library of the clinics for occupational medicine identified 306 articles. Full text articles, available in English and German, reporting the point CVD in an occupational context were included.

Results: Twenty three articles were identified. Various studies showed that women who spend an average of eight or more hours sitting or standing at work have a significantly higher risk of developing varicose veins than women who spend four or fewer hours in these positions. In contrast, no clear correlation between sedentary work and varicose veins can be established in men. However, there is a correlation between the number of years men worked in a standing position and the severity of CVD. A large observational study of >6000 randomly selected men and women concluded that the relative risk of hospitalization for varicose vein surgery increased 1.8-fold for those whose jobs consisted predominantly of standing or walking. The significance of sitting and standing as occupational cofactors in the development of varicose veins and venous symptoms was highlighted in a study of 2,000 randomly selected French volunteers. While height and a higher BMI had little correlation with the development of ankle edema, there was a significant link with activity (sitting and standing). Venous pressure varies depending on the position of the body: approx. 5mmHg when lying down, 80mmHg when standing, 45-60mmHg when seated, and 25-30mmHg when walking. Patients with CVD exhibit muscular changes including atrophy of the myofibrils, dilatation, proliferation of the interfascial veins and inflammatory changes, which further reduce the pumping function. Lack of muscle activity causes endothelial dysfunction, increases vascular permeability of the veins, and activates leukocytes and platelets. Studies show that compression therapy can lessen this effect.

Conclusion: Occupational stress impacts the venous system more than the risk factors of body weight, gender and predisposition. Hence preventive measures - especially in the workplace - have the potential to be highly effective. Optimal venous hemodynamics in the workplace can be achieved through interventional changes to the work environment, the individual, and the organization of work. The three intervention strategies are to be applied in an additive manner.

Keywords: CVD, occupational disease, workplace, economic sector, varicose veins

Adhesion molecules and their ligands in patients with varicose veins

Roman Kalinin1, Igor Suchkov1, Natalya Korotkova1, Nina Mzhavanadze1

1Ryazan State Medical Univeristy, Russia

Background: interactions between the cells as well as between the cells and extracellular matrix proteins are mediated by the adhesion molecules and are some of the key biochemical processes. Initial stages of leukocyte adhesion to the endothelium are mediated by non-specific non-covalent interactions between the selectins and their glycoprotein ligands, particularly, P-selectin and P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1 (PSGL-1). This pilot study was aimed at assessing the expression of P-selectin and PSGL-1 in patients with varicose veins.

Methods: the study included 24 patients (12 females, 12 males), aged 47.5 (44; 57), among which 12 subjects had symptomatic varicose veins, clinical class C2s according to the CEAP classification, and 12 subjects were used as control (healthy volunteers). The participants of the study were comparable in age and gender. Serum samples were isolated from peripheral venous whole blood samples. Quantitative measurement of P-selectin and its glycoprotein ligand PSGL-1 was performed using the Sandwich Enzyme-Linked ImmunoSorbent Assay (ELISA) with ELISA Kit for Selectin, Platelet (SELP) (catalogue № SEA569Hu), PSGL-1 ELISA kit (catalogue № SEA985Hu), and Stat Fax 2100 analyzer (microplate reader) (Awareness technology Inc. PalmCity, FL 34990, USA).

Results: P-selectin levels in patients with varicose veins were 55% lower as compared to the healthy volunteers, 176179.2 pg/ml and 96944.5 pg/ml, respectively (p≤0,05). The level of high affinity P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1 (PSGL-1) was 70.5% higher in patients with varicose veins as compared to control, 1.9 ng/ml and 6.45 ng/ml, respectively (p≤0,05). Endothelial cell damage is further caused by the leukocyte recruiting and leukocyte invasion. As a result, soluble fragments of PSGL-1 are detected in the blood.

Conclusion: initial stages of chronic venous disease, namely, varicose veins class C2 according to the CEAP classification, are characterized by a lower expression of P-selectin and increased expression of P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1 (PSGL-1). Adhesion molecules and their ligands may play an important role in vein-specific inflammation.

Keywords: venous inflammation, endothelial dysfunction, varicose veins, selectins, adhesion molecules

Role and place negative pressure wound therapy in the management of large chronic venous leg ulcers

Ravshan Sunnatov1, Boboyor Keldiyorov1, Dilmurod Ganiev1

1AkfaMedline Hospital, Tashkent, Uzbekistan

Background: Chronic venous insufficiency which may lead venous leg ulcers (VLU) are medical and social problems, associated with chronic disability, diminished quality of life and high health-care costs. Treatment is are often very slow, and high rate of recurrence even when achieving healing of ulcers

Methods: Our study included 27 patients treated with chronic venous ulcers (CVU) larger than 50 cm2, in the AkfaMedline hospital (Tashkent, Uzbekistan) during 2018-2021 yy. In all cases complex treatments were included negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) with split skin grafting (SSG). All patients were done clinical examinations and ultrasound Doppler study, 8 patients (obese patients) additionally were done MRI or CT phlebography to define causes venous hypertensions. 11 (40.7%) patients’ causes venous hypertension and VLU was primary varicose disease in the system of GSV or SSV, 14 (51.9%) patients were postphlebitic syndrome and secondary varicose disease, and 2 (7.4%) cases local venous hypertension due to incompetence deep veins and communicant veins valves. To decrease hypertension in the superficial venous system all patients primary were treated by the endovenous laser ablation, ultrasound guided ligation communicant veins, laser ablation communicant veins, miniphlebectomy, and some cases used additionally Sclerotherapy. After primary debridement VLU all patients were applied NPWT 2 times each one during for 3 days in continued regime 100-125 mm Hg st. negative pressure. When achieved clean, adequate granulated tissue was done SSG venous ulcers and NPWT continued 2 times each one during for 4 days.

Results: Most of our cases (96.3%) achieved full healing applied skin grafts and healing venous ulcers during 6-10 weeks period. In 1 (3.7%) patient was observed delayed VLU more than 2 months. 2 (7.4%) patients had recurrence of small venous ulcer in the follow-up period, were done additionally Sclerotherapy for decrease venous hypertension, which helped to heal recurrent venous ulcers with aseptic dressings and elastic compression therapy.

Large venous ulcer

large venous ulcer before operation, patient's with venous hypertension and secondary varicose disease

SSG VLU post operatin

Patient post operation EVLA GSV and communicant veins, NPWT, SSG - 5th day post operation

Conclusion: Complex treatment of CVU with including NPWT and SSG helped total healing of VLU most of cases. NPWT after correction venous hypertension provides quick wound-bed preparation and high rate skin graft intake which help long term venous ulcer treatment.

Keywords: Venous ulcer, Chronic venous insufficiency, NPWT, split skin grafting

How innocent is using the glue treatment for venous insufficiency? Complications

Ercan Keleş1, Şahin Bozok1

1Bakırçay University Çigli Training and Research Hospital

Background: Cyanoacrylate ablation therapy is one of the most commonly chosen treatment options for venous insufficiency, and therefore complications may be more frequent and varied during treatment. This study investigated the complications of cyanoacrylate ablation therapy performed at our center.

Methods: In our center, 116 patients who received cyanoacrylate therapy for venous insufficiency were retrospectively over a 16-month period. A Variclose ven ablation system was used in the treatment of these patients.

Results: The mean age of the patients was 49.8 (±13.2; min-max 20-58) years. 54.3% (n=63) of the patients were male. Underlying medical conditions were evaluated: 25.9% (n=30) of patients had diabetes mellitus, 27.6% (n=32) had hypertension, and 11.2% (n=13) had hyperlipidemia. Complications occured in 11 (9.5%) patients, and eight patients (72.7%) were male (p=0.197). Phlebitis was observed in five patients (4.3%), cellulitis in four patients (3.4%), abscess in one patient (0.9%), deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in one patient (0.9%). The mean age of patients who devoloped complications was 43.2% (±9.8; min-max 27-58) years. When comparing the mean age of patients who developed and did not devolop complications, it was found that patients with devoloped complications were younger (43 vs 50; p=0.041). Only one patient who devoloped complications had a history of chronic disease (p=0.027).

Conclusion: Our study found that one in ten patients devoloped complications and that patients with complications were younger and less likely to have chronic disease. Knowing the potential complications of performing cyanoacrylate ablation treatment may enable us to develop the proper behavior.

Keywords: Cyanoacrylate, venous insufficiency, ven ablation, glue

Comparative characteristics of surgical treatment methods in patients with complicated forms of chronic venous insufficiency

Tokan Sultanaliev1, Irlan Sagandykov1, Meruyert Akzhigitova1, Almas Kenessarov1

1Department of vascular surgery, National research oncology center, Nur-Sultan city, Kazakhstan

Background: The problem of surgical treatment of complicated forms of CVI is relevant all over the world. Modern phlebology considers incompetent perforating veins as one of the main pathogenetic elements of the occurrence of trophic disorders in CVI.

Methods: This study summarizes the data of a retrospective analysis of the results of surgical treatment of 32 patients with a complicated form of CVI, who developed against the background of varicose veins, who were treated at the vascular surgery center of the NROC for the period from 2018 to 2022. Among the observed patients, women predominated - 62,5%, men were 37,5%. The age of the patients ranged from 42 to 68 years. Trophic ulcers in these patients were located in the lower third of the medial surface of the lower leg. The largest linear size of a trophic ulcer was measured. Up to 1 cm. – 16,6%, from 1-5 cm. - 58,3%, more than 5 cm. - 25% of patients. All the studied patients were divided into 2 groups in accordance with the CEAP classification: I (main) group consisted of 19 patients (59,37%), II (control) group consisted of 13 patients (40,62%) with a complicated form of CVI. The VCSS scale was adopted as a scale for assessing the severity of CVI. The sum of points in the main group with an average value of 20. In the control with an average value of 21. The diagnosis of the lower leg veins was carried out by ultrasound duplex scanning. In the main group, endoscopic surgery technique was used. Hospital bed days averaged 4-5 days. In the control group, subfascial ligation of perforant veins from the traditional Linton access. Hospital bed days averaged 7-10 days.

Results: Regression of trophic disorders of the lower leg in patients in the main group proceeded much faster. The early reduction of the trophic ulcer is due to the minimization of the surgical wound as a result of the use of endovideosurgical techniques, which creates favorable conditions for tissue repair.This effect allowed us to reduce the bed-day in patients in the main group by 2 times. Relative to bed days in the hospital period, it was possible to reduce the size of ulcers in 9 patients (61,2%) in the main group, and in 7 patients (63,3%) in the control group, as well as to reduce the risk of postoperative complications.

Conclusion: The use of endovideosurgical techniques in patients with complicated forms of CVI showed good hospital results for early healing processes of trophic ulcers, reduction of postoperative complications and the number of bed days.

Keywords: Endoscopic vein dissection, Subfascial vein dissection, Linton

Analysis of rare events after foam sclerotherapy in a single center (2013-2021)

Enric Roche1, Cristina Marqués1

1Clinica Vascular Barcelona

Background: This is an audit of AEs over an 9-year-long period, in order to identify causes and/or potential risky practices.

Methods: The study was conducted as a review of a prospective database of patients treated with foam sclerotherapy between the years of 2013 and 2021. Data were analysed globally, as well as separately in two periods: 2013-2016 and 2017-2021. An analysis with descriptive statistics was conducted. For the procedures, polidocanol foam was prepared with a magnetic stirrer and room air. AEs analysed included visual disturbances, neurologic symptoms, chest pain and anxiety and deep vein thrombosis. Aesthetic results were not included.

Results: From January 2013 to December 2021, 3171 sessions were performed on 740 patients (611 women (82,5%) and 129 men (17,7%)). A total of 32 AEs were registered for 23 patients, 1 man and 22 women (average age: 50,3, Range: 30-74). Incidence of AEs:1,01% of sessions (3,1% of patients). 68,75% (22/32) of events were registered in aesthetic veins treatments and 31,35% in other type of varicose veins. Out of all AEs, patients reported 12 visual disturbances (0,38%), 9 neurological events (0,28%), 7 events of chest discomfort/anxiety (0,22%), 2 cases of DVT (0,06%), 1 case of cellulitis (0,03%) and 1 Tako-Tsubo (0,03%). Medical history of migraine was present in 30,4% (7/23). PFO 3 positive of 5 checked. Neurological events were diverse with immediate recovery. Incidence and type of AEs differed along the time so data was analysed in two periods. The 1st period (2013-2016) included 355 patients and 1162 treatments. The 2nd period (2017-2021) included 385 patients and 2009 treatments. During the 1st period, AEs were reported for 2,07% of sessions (4,2% of patients), compared to 0,4% of sessions (2,08% of patients) for the 2nd period (p<0.05). Comparative type of AE in 1st period vs 2nd period goes as follows: visual disturbances, 8 events (0,69%) vs 4 events (0,20%) (p<0,05); neurologic symptoms, 9 events (0,77%) vs 0 events (p<0,05); chest discomfort, 7 events (0,22%) vs 0 events (p< 0,05). The average volume in global series was 10,2cc with average % Pol 0,4%. For the 1st period, the volume was 11,6cc and Pol 0,26%; for the 2nd period it was 7,5cc and Pol 0,65% (p<0.05). Ten patients with previous AEs followed treatment using O2CO2 without any AE.

Conclusion: A self-audit of AEs is advisable to analyse own results. The total volume of foam injected was related to higher complications. Migraine history should be asked routinely to identify a risk group. Even though the global complications rate was low, foam sclerotherapy is not exempt of complications.

Keywords: foam sclerotherapy, adverse events, migraine, visual disturbances, neurologic symptoms

Cryo Laser And Cryo Sclerotherapy (CLaCS) vs MicroSclerotherapy

Dmitrii Rosukhovskii1

1Mentor Clinic, St Petersburg, Russia

Background: The novel method of Crio-Laser And Cryo-Sclerotherapy (CLACS) has gained popularity in recent years. CLACS has a synergistic effect of laser flashes after skin cooling and sclerosant injections on the reticular and telangiectatic veins. Micro Sclerotherapy (MS) is frequently used for the esthetic treatment of reticular veins and telangiectasia of the lower limbs. These treatments sometimes lead to low satisfaction with the immediate result in the first 2-3 weeks after the treatment due to ekhymosis and the appearance of hyperpigmentation and matting.The aim of the study was to compare the effectiveness of MS and CLACS results.

Methods: After skin cooling all dilated veins were treated with Microsecond NdYAG 1064nm laser for CLAСS therapy with energy density range 90J/cm2; then MS of the same vessel was performed with a Sodium Tetradecyl Sulfate 3 mg/ml (STS3% ex tempora was mixed with a Glucose 40% in a 1:9 ratio to increase the viscosity of the solution). MS was performed according to a similar technique in the control group. Consecutive 188 adults patients dissatisfied with their appearance of dilated veins in the legs (C1 class according to the CEAP), were included in the study. Saphenous or deep vein reflux was the exclusion criteria. The effectiveness of the procedures was evaluated by an independent expert on a 5-point scale by comparing photos before, after 1-2 weeks and after 6-10 weeks. Immediate results after one week were traced in 147 (89.6%) after CLaCS and 41 (86.7%) after MS. Long-term results of CLaCS were assessed in 121 (74.2%), and after MS – in 22 patients (51.1%).

Results: CLaCS and MS groups were comparable in age (p=0.584) and gender (p=0.69). Most of the applicants were between 31 and 40 (42%), 96% were women. The average effectiveness score on a five-point scale for evaluating 1-2 weeks after the CLaCS and MS were 3.9+-0.6 and 2.3+-0.8, respectively. In CLaCS group the reduction of reticular and teleangiectayic veins more than 50% after one session was found in 105 (71.4%) pts; less than 50% in 42 (28.6%) pts. The reduction of more than 50% veins in MS groupe was found in 4 (7.2%) pts; less than 50% in 37(92.8%) pts (Table). Severe matting was found in two patients (1.4%) after CLaCS and in 9 (22%) after MS (p<0.0001). The average score in the groups 6-10 weeks after the procedures was (4.5+-0.4) CLaCS and (3.8+-0.7) MS (p<0.0001).

Conclusion: Improvement of the appearance of the skin after CLaCS treatment occurred faster, with a decrease in the likelihood of hyperpigmentation and matting, compared with sclerotherapy. These differences remained significant after 6-10 weeks.

Keywords: CLaCS, telangiectasia, matting, NdYAG laser, hyperpigmentation

The results of Endovenous laser ablation of varicose tributaries of the limbs with lasers with a wavelength of 1470 nm and 1940 nm

Shokhzod Zokirkhonov1, Surat Temirov1

1Vein clinic "Phlebolife"

Background: Chronic diseases of the veins retain their relevance to this day. Despite the emergence of minimally invasive methods for the treatment of varicose veins (VV), the search for more gentle approaches to the treatment of this problem continues. In recent years, the so-called Total endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) has appeared, in which, in addition to obliteration of the trunk vein, varicose tributaries are also subjected to laser coagulation, thereby without resorting to miniphlebectomy. This method showed good results and, with good assimilation of the technique, reduced the operation time in comparison with miniphlebectomy. The purpose of this study was a comparative analysis of the results of Endovenous laser ablation of varicose tributaries (VT) with lasers with a wavelength of 1470 nm and 1940 nm.

Methods: Over the past 6 months, in our clinic, 52 patients with VV on 65 limbs underwent EVLO of VT using Bare-tip laser fibers from the company IPG. The patients were divided into two groups, the first group of patients (12 limbs) for EVLA of VT used a laser with a wavelength of 1470 nm, in the energy supply mode at a power of 6 W, while the energy was 60 J / cm. In the second group of patients (53 limbs), a laser with a wavelength of 1940 nm was used for EVLA of VT, in the energy supply mode at a power of 4.5 W, while the energy was 45 J/cm. The technique was as follows, under the control of ultrasound, a phased catheterization of varicose tributaries of the thigh or lower leg was performed with 18G angiocatheters, about from 3 to 8 catheters were used, after the Bare-tip fiber an inserted into each angiocatater, tumescent anesthesia and subsequent laser coagulation of the veins were performed.

EVLO of varicose vein tributaries

Background: There is no common consensus with clinical correlation between medical follow-up and surgical planning time in patients with lower extremity superficial venous insufficiency, which is common in the community. In our study, we aimed to present the most appropriate surgical time and results in symptomatic patients.

Methods: Our patients who were admitted to the outpatient clinic and followed up due to symptomatic lower extremity superficial venous insufficiency between September 2018 and April 2022 were reviewed retrospectively. We used three parameters to decide on the operation in these symptomatic patients. In these patients, CEAP ≥ 2, reflux ≥ grade III, vein diameter >5mm were evaluated, and the decision to operate was made in patients who were found to be positive in these three parameters. The patients whose three parameters were not positive were followed up with variegated stockings and drug therapy. At the control examination performed three months later, pain scores and symptoms were compared and a significant difference was searched.

Results: Thirty-eight of 156 patients with symptomatic venous insufficiency that we followed up were operated because these three parameters were positive. The remaining 118 patients were followed up with medical treatment and various stockings, since three parameters did not positivity. Pain scores and other symptoms were evaluated at the 3rd month follow-up of these patients. When the pain scores were compared, it was determined that there was a statistically significant difference between them compared to the pre-treatment (p<0.01). There was no significant difference between CEAP scores, insufficiency degrees and vessel diameters (p>0.05). Significant improvement was observed in the postoperative symptoms and pain scores of the operated patients (p<0.01). No complications were observed in any of the patients during the follow-up period.

Conclusion: There is still no consensus on the treatment of lower extremity venous insufficiency, which is very common. In our clinical experience, we performed surgery on patients with CEAP≥2, reflux ≥ grade III, and vein diameter >5mm.In patients who did not reach the level of the coexistence of these three parameters, a serious improvement in symptoms was observed with medical treatment and various stockings, and the operation was no longer needed or postponed. Therefore, we think that evaluating these three parameters together will be a guide in surgical planning.

The ECD showed the saphenopopliteal anastomosis patent and GSV dilatated (11.4 mm) and insufficient with an insufficient dilated tributary in the middle third of the thigh finding several leg varicose tributaries. Patient was followed up until 2021 when he died of COVID-19.

May-Husni procedure

Conclusion: the ligation of veins in the deep venous system (DVS) can trigger severe manifestation and segmental obstructions should be restored; these restorations may have a high success rate and are durable; the patient must be accompanied throughout his life and treated as soon as the first signs of chronic venous disease appear.

Background: Nutcracker syndrome (NCS) occurs as a result of compression of the left renal vein by the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. For many years, surgical treatment of this syndrome has been carried out by switching blood flow from the left renal vein to the inferior vena cava or iliac vein by open or laparoscopic interventions. Endovascular technologies are also used, but their effectiveness and prospects are still controversial.

Methods: In 2022 in the Department of Vascular Surgery of Krasnodar Regional Hospital, a technique of treating NCS using a Da Vinci Xi® robot was developed and implemented. Before the robotic stage, VSM ex situ explantation and preparation is performed. The robotic stage includes the isolation of the left renal vein, the isolation of the common iliac vein, the imposition of temporary clips on them (Figure 1). Further, holes corresponding to the diameter of the prepared VSM shunt are formed in the LRV and VIC. The VSM is delivered through the port into the abdominal cavity. The location of the VSM shunt with a preserved valve apparatus ensures unidirectional blood flow from the LRV to the VIC. Anastamoses LRV\VSM and VIC\VSM are performed using a Prolen 6\0 (Ethicon) thread (Figure 2).

Results: In 2022, two operations were performed using Da Vinci Xi® robot technology. The total operation time is 141±22 min. The time of temporary compression of the left renal vein is 20±4.5 minutes. The total time of robotic application of proximal and distal anastomosis is 30±8.5 minutes. The intraoperative blood loss did not exceed 50 ml. The postoperative period proceeded without peculiarities and complications. CT phlebography and selective venous shunt phlebography were performed to control the unidirectional patency of the structure. We can talk about a decrease in venous hypertension in the LRV basing on a decrease in its diameter by 20-30% 3-4 days after surgery.

Conclusion: LRV-VIC bypass surgery of the autovenous VSM using the Da Vinci Xi® robot is a highly effective surgical intervention for NCS. The creation of unidirectional autovenous flow through the shunt between the LRV and the VIC reduces hypertension in the LRV. Nevertheless, the venous outflow from the LRV into the pool of the inferior vena cava significantly increases, bypassing the area of stenosis. The diameter of the LRV decreases and clinical manifestations are reduced. Additional experience and long term observations are needed to assess the effectiveness of this operation in its new technological performance. The robotic bypass surgery is the method of choice for the NCS treatment, characterised by a low complication rate and optimistic early postoperative results.

Keywords: Nutcracker syndrome, Robot-assisted bypass surgery, Left renal vein

This tool is the Venous Mapping (VM), a cartography composed of strokes, colors and geometric shapes that provides information on the characteristics of the venous system and allows sharing the same criteria, improving communication, unifying reports and standardizing venous treatment. Background: Patients with superficial venous thrombosis (SVT) are at increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Systemic anticoagulation therapy (ACT) was suggested as standard treatment by the current guidelines. However, the optimal duration of anticoagulation still is unknown. This study aimed to determine the association between the duration of ACT and the risk of further VTE in patients with SVT.

Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis were performed using searches Medline and Cochrane Library databases in September 2021 according to the previously developed protocol (CRD42021271486). Papers that provided VTE incidence within mid-term follow-up of ≥ 45 days in patients who received any systemic anticoagulation were included. Patients were categorized into subgroups according to the course of treatment: (1) no ACT (0 days), (2) ACT of ≤ 14 days, (3) ACT of 15–30 days, (4) ACT of 31–45 days, and (5) ACT of ≥ 45 days. Reported events were transformed to events per 100 patient-years, and a random-effects model was used to calculate pooled rates for proportions. The primary outcome (VTE) was a combination of SVT progression or recurrence and/or the occurrence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE).

Results: Twenty-one studies (ten randomized clinical trials and 11 cohort studies) of 12,272 patients were included in the quantitative synthesis. Minimum rates of VTE and SVT recurrence or progression were observed with the ACT duration of 31–45 days were 16.2 and 9.1 events per 100 patient-years, respectively. Minimum rates of DVT and PE that were observed with the treatment duration of 15–30 days were 6.0 and 0.9 events per 100 patient-years, respectively. Short-term treatment of ≤ 14 days was associated with the highest VTE rates even when compared with no ACT. The most common risk factors for VTE included male sex, malignancy, personal history of DVT, PE, or SVT, and thrombosis of non-varicose veins.

Conclusion: Prolonged systemic anticoagulation is associated with the tendency to cause a decrease in VTE rates in patients with lower limb SVT.

Types of endovenous treatment (p=0.794 for VenaSeal, p=0.421 for radiofrequency ablation, p=0.523 for endovenous laser ablation, and p=0.376 for ultrasonographic foam sclerotherapy) and the numbers of phlebectomy (3.61±2.3 in no SSWI group vs. 4.40±5.0 in SSWI group) was not associated with postoperative SSWI incidence. In the logistic regression test, the preoperative great saphenous vein size was a unique risk factor for postoperative SSWI (Odd Ratio 1.442, 95% confidence interval 1.12-1.80, p=0.004)

Conclusion: Both nPA and PA strategy has a very low and comparable incidence of SSWI after combined endovenous and concomitant phlebectomy for chronic venous disease treatment. nPA strategy did not increase post-procedural surgical site wound infection. Douglas Poschinger-Figueiredo1, Cristiane Ferreira de Araujo Gomes1, Leonardo Silveira de Castro1, Eduardo de Oliveira Rodrigues Neto1, Yanna Cristhina Moreira Thomaz1, Eric Paiva Vilela1, Lívia Ramos Carvalho Marchon1, Carlos Eduardo Virgini-Magalhães1

1Rio de Janeiro State University

Background: Both Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and ultrasound guided foam sclerotherapy (USGFS) have been described as safe and successful treatment options for varicose vein treatment. However, there are limited data on the efficacy and safety of these two procedures combined, especially in patients with large great saphenous vein (GSV) diameters. This study assessed the outcomes and impact on the quality-of-life following one-step outpatient treatment with RFA for large GSV reflux associated to USGFS for the associated varicose veins.

Methods: This was a retrospective, single-centre, analytical cohort, with ethical committee approval, conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. Thirty symptomatic patients having reflux in the GSV and varicosities (CEAP C3 to C6) were treated with RFA and USGFS simultaneously, in a single-step procedure, from March 2016 to December 2016. They were followed up at 1 week, 6 months, 1 and 3 years. Clinical outcomes, changes in the Quality of Life (QOL) questionnaires SF-36, visual analog scale (VAS), VCSS and AVVQ, evolutive vein occlusion rates were assessed by duplex ultrasound, and ulcer closure was checked.

Results: The sample was divided into two groups: Group 1 - GSV diameter ≥ 13.0 mm (median 19.0 [14–24]), with 17 subjects, and Group 2 - GSV diameter ≤ 12.9 mm (median 10.3 [10–12]), with 16 subjects. No major adverse event was observed, and the postoperative minor adverse event rates were similar between the two groups. A significant improvement was observed in VCSS and AVVQ from the preoperative levels to the sixth month and the third-year follow-up for both groups. Twelve of 13 ulcers had healed at 1 year and remained closed until 3 years. The entire sample had a significant increase in all short form 36 domains, except for mental health in the Group 2 (GSV ≥ 13.0 mm). The overall first week occlusion rate for the whole sample was 90.9% and 69.7% at the 3-year follow-up. No difference in the occlusion rate was observed between the two groups at any time.

Conclusion: In this study, the outpatient combined technique was safe and feasible in this population with no major adverse events, despite the large diameters of GSV and a considerable proportion of leg ulcers. Within the third year, the total sample and both saphenous vein diameter range subgroups showed equivalent improvement in VAS, VCSS, and AVVQ quality of life questionnaires, satisfactory axial occlusion, and maintained ulcer closure.

Background: Aesthetic phlebology is becoming an increasingly popular area of interest in the venous world. Most facial veins can be treated by transcutaneous laser, targeting the blood within the vein. However, a small proportion of prominent facial veins are too large for this non-invasive treatment. Since 2015, we have performed facial phlebectomy under local anaesthetic for these veins (Figure 1). The aim of this study is to report the patient satisfaction in the small cohort of patients we have treated to date.

Methods: A retrospective review was made from the operating records to identify those patients undergoing facial phlebectomy in our institution. Patients were identified and then contacted by e-mail and, where necessary, by telephone. Patients were asked whether subjectively they thought the treatment had worked. Then using a five-point scale, they were asked to rate: the disappearance of the veins, their scars, their feeling about their treatment overall, and finally, whether they would recommend this treatment to friends and family.

Results: 22 patients were contacted, and 13 replied (response rate 59%). Unfortunately, one of the e-mails was corrupted, and only 12 were available for analysis. Of these 12 patients, 10 were female and two male. The mean age was 45.4 years (range 28-64). The veins treated were 8 temporal veins, 14 periorbital veins, one vein on the cheek and one vein on the upper eyelid. The subjective comments range from "my facial vein was fully removed with no pain or scarring" to "the treatment has not been that effective". The results of the five-point grading system are tabulated in Table 1.

Right facial phlebectomy

Before and after right facial phlebectomy

Conclusion: There have been an increasing number of meetings dedicated to aesthetic phlebology over the last few years, reflecting a growing interest in patients seeking aesthetic phlebology treatments and doctors starting to provide them. One of the main areas of aesthetic phlebology is the treatment of facial veins. Although traditionally this has been thought of as the treatment of thread veins around the nose and on the cheeks, as well as smaller green veins around the eyes and temples, larger veins have often been passed over as "untreatable". This study has shown that in a small group of patients selected as potentially treatable, phlebectomy under local anaesthetic can result in high patient satisfaction. However, even though most results are very good, the occasional poor result or unhappy patient mandates careful consenting as this is a cosmetic rather than medical procedure.

2Angiocor, Messina/Palermo/Agrigento

Background: Suffering from hemorrhoids is a common pathology in countries with a high standard of living. Methods: We have treated 100 patients with variable degree ( from I to IV degree) of hemorroidal disease and proctorrhagia from August 2021 to March 2022 using Medical Device to standardize the foam.Endoscopic examination was carried out using a dedicated flexible endoscopic video with a diameter of 10 mm, only in particular cases we have used sedation. For the anoscopic procedure we didn’t use sedation Each treatment was executed cranially to the pectinate line, where the sensitive innervation is absent.The foam of Lauromacrogol 2% or 3% has been prepared with medical device, a machine that allows to obtain a standardized sclerosing foam.The quantity of injected medication per individual hemorroidal mass was never higher than 2 cc, with a maximum of 6 cc during each session.Each session has an average duration of 8 minutes (range 6-12 minutes) with endoscopic tecnique, 4 minutes with anoscopic tecnique At the end of the procedure patients returned to their usual daily activity.

Results: We had organised a follow-up of three months, with controls and eventually repetition of procedures in the case of persistence of symptoms or incomplete sclerosis. Each procedure was carried on every 20 days, without complications.We carried out a total of 250 treatments on 100 patients.At the end of the follow-up all the patients had improved quality of life, with resolution of bleeding and of anemia.

Conclusion: We prefer use flexible endoscopic tecnique for the hemorrhoids of III or IV degree For the I and II degree use the anoscopy tecnique In case of hemorrhage urgency we use anoscopic or endoscopic tecnique depends on the degree or amount of bleeding

Background: Lymphedema is estimated to effect between 100 – 300 million people worldwide, India has a higher proportion due to tropical problems like Filariasis and Podoconiosis over and above general causes like cancer, venous disease trauma, old age, obesity etc. Not only do the patients get a disfiguring swelling but they also get repeated infections in the limb called Adeno-Dermato-Lymphangitis Attacks (ADLA). These are mostly gram positive in origin and best managed through Penicillin. CDT (Comprehensive Decongestive Therapy) is considered the worldwide gold standard for management of Lymphoedema. CDT is labor intensive requiring physical interaction with a trained therapist who are expensive as well as hard to find. This is yet to become commonplace in India. It consists of two parts, Initiation Phase done in the hospital, and Maintenance phase, at home. MLD or Manual Lymphatic Drainage is a major component of Initiation phase, but lately its relevance has been discounted. We have been managing Lymphedema - largely without MLD at our clinic since 25 years, giving good outcomes. Training on self bandaging has been a major component of our processes. Recently due to COVID some patients from far, could not reach us for care initiation. So we decided to provide counselling and training totally online. A case report is presented.

Methods: We get lymphedema patients come from across India. After diagnosis, we initiate CDT on an ambulatory basis along with long term Penicillin, counselling, training and motivation to continue self care at home. The duration of initiation phase has of late reduced great from the initial 7-10 days, as patients and care givers are taught how to self bandage. Patients are encouraged to make videos for later recall. An Electronic Medical Record system which has a special module for Lymphedema is used for care documentation. Penicillin was prescribed and patient sent appropriate bandage sets. Online training provided not only of self tying of bandage but also how to take measurements.

training collage

After another two months the limb was stable at 35% volume difference from original.

Table showing results with calculated volumes marked out

Background: The minimally invasive therapy of varicosis is increasingly finding its way into the clinical routine of vascular therapists. The apparent simplicity of the procedure also tempts doctors of other specialties to carry out endovenous therapies. While there is now manageable data on thermal-endovenous procedures, treatment with cyanoacrylate is largely unknown. A long-term practical experience with cyanoacrylate has therefore rarely been published so far.

Methods: Between January 2014 and January 2022, a total of 687 patients were treated with the cyanoacrylate method (VenaSeal procedure) at the Center for Vascular Medicine Düsseldorf in Germany. During the same period, 1762 veins were treated by thermal methods such as radiofrequency or laser and respectively in 1380 by conventional open crossectomy and stripping. We tracked and followed up on our patients retrospectively in a follow-up of up to 36 months in terms of success rate and complications.

Results: It was often treated single vein 87%, namely more SSV than GSV. Patients have always had Chronic venos diseas St. II and III (CEAP C2-C6). 63 x allergic reactions (9.1%), 35 x phlebitides (5%), 3 foreign body granulomas and a pulmonary artery embolism have been documented.The primary closure was 100%. Partial recentalisation (2.5%) was documented in 17 patients and complete recanalisation (0.3%) in a further 2 patients. After 12 months, 26 partial sewerage systems (3.8%) and 3 complete re-sewers (0.44%) were detected in total. The closure rate after 36 months was 95.7%.

Conclusion: In summary, the VenaSeal procedure of the trunk vein can represent a real alternative to conventional therapy and thermal procedures due to the very good results in our collective as well as in the comparative studies. This method can be trusted more in order to be able to generate even more experience and even more data. However, the practitioner should always choose the best possible form of therapy for his patients.The location of the target vein plays an important role here. Most of the re-sewerage systems were carried out in the GSV observed. Taking this fact into account, I believe that conventional therapy and thermal therapy should be avoided in the treatment of SSV.

Jinwon Jeon1

Background: Background : Cyanoacrylate closure(CAC), one of nonthermal and nontumescent, has been introduced. Sine 2017 CAC, commercial name is VenaSeal, has been widely used for varicose vein treatment in South Korea. It has many advantages – short operation time, easy to use, little postoperative pain, no compression stocking apply, etc. But it has also disadvantages – especially in postoperative allergic reaction. This study aimed to anlayze postoperative allergic reaction.

Methods: Previously it has been called Phlebitis-Like Abnormal Reaction(PLAR). But actually all PLARs are not phlebitis but delayed allergic reaction. So we call it PostCyanoacrylate Allergic Reaction(PoCAR) to included every case of CAC induced allergic reaction. PoCAR is graded as location and duration time. The location was divided local and systemic.(recorded 1 and 2) The duration time was divided < 1 month, < 6 months, > 6 months.(recorded A, B, C)

Results: A total 862 patients, 2564 incompetent GSV & SSV were treated with CAC procedure. There were 577 patients of PoCAR.(66.9%) The location was 1 and 2.(92.8% and 7.2%) The duration time was A, B, C(87.6%, 11.8%, 0.6%). PoCAR were 1A, 1B, 1C(87.3%, 5.2%, 0.3%). PoCAR were 2A, 2B, 2C(0.3%, 6.6%, 0.3%). Usually PoCAR is improved with short period anti-allergic and anti-inflammatory agents. But in some cases it is terribly severe and long lasting. We report 2 severe long lasting PoCAR(2C) cases, eventually had operation to remove it

Conclusion: One of the most frequent postoperative complication of CAC is PostCyanoacrylate Allergic Reaction(PoCAR). Protect and reduce the possibility of PoCAR, thorough history taking of allergic reaction and meticulous operation skill are essential. Unfortunately if PoCAR grade 2C occurs, early decision of removal operation and meticulous technique are essential to resolve this problem and improve patient’s quality of life.

According to SIC-DIC scores obtained through SOFA scores and clinical parameters, patients who reach DIC levels (SIC>5) have an increased rate of mortality (Tables 2 and 3).

According to SIC-DIC scores obtained through SOFA scores and clinical parameters, patients who reach DIC levels (SIC>5) have an increased rate of mortality (Tables 2 and 3).

Conclusion: Through our findings, we wanted to describe when COVID-19 patients who are hospitalized should receive anticoagulant treatment.
